_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
Enterprise Propane Terminals and Storage
Alma Terminal 
RMP Executive Summary

EPA ID:  1000 0016 5607

At the Enterprise Propane Terminals and Storage Alma Terminal we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.

The Enterprise Propane Terminals and Storage Alma Terminal is owned by Enterprise Products Operating, LLC and operated by Enterprise Propane Terminals and Storage, LLC.  The Alma Terminal is a LPG storage and loading terminal connected to the Dixie Pipeline interstate LPG pipeline system.    The process is regulated by the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard for highly hazardous chemicals.

We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
* Emergency Response Programs
* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and chemical-specific prevention steps
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Alma Terminal that are regulated by EPA's RMP rule.  

Facility Description

The Alma Terminal engages in the pipeline receipt and storage of liquefied propane under pressure, and the loading of propane tank trucks.    The process is regulated by Federal OSH

A 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 3 facility.

The facility receives, stores and distributes LPG.  There are five tanks used to receive propane from the Dixie Pipeline system and to store the propane prior to loading into bulk tanker trucks for delivery.  The tanks are administratively controlled to hold and not exceed 80% of their capacity.  The facility consists of pressure storage tanks, a truck loading dock, associated piping, valves and other miscellaneous equipment.    

In our process we use the following chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

There are no toxic materials contained on site above the threshold limits.

Flammables

Propane is a finished product which is received into five storage tanks.  This material is routed from these tanks to the loading docks for distribution.  Ethyl mercaptan is stored at Alma Terminal and is added to the propane as an odorant during the loading process.  The ethyl-mercaptan at Alma Terminal is present below the threshold quantity for this chemical specified in the RMP Rule. 

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenarios(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.

Worst Case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemical

No toxic material above the threshold quantity on site.

Alternate Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemical

No toxic material above the threshold quantity on site.

Worse Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This simulation involves the rupture or failure of a propane storage tank resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.

This scenario assumes there would be no mitigation.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting of the Risk Management Plan

Alternate Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The alternate release scenario is a simulated release from a loading rack filter thermal relief valve on an adjacent, non-active loading rack.  The relief valve is assumed to open to vent pressure due to blocked-in thermal expansion of the propane, with the valve failing to reseat, venting the entire quantity of the filter into the loading rack area.  The filter has been calculated to contain 37 gallons (157 pounds) of propane that is released into the loading rack area and explodes in a vapor cloud explosion.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown Devices would ensure the isolation of the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation is contained in the data elements.

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Bacon County Sheriff's Department Emergency Management District, which includes the local Alma Police department, Bacon County Sheriff's De

partment, Bacon County Fire Department, and Emergency Medical Service.

In the event of an accidental release, local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the alarm, shut off the source from a safe location and contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the local Police and Fire Departments.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Enterprise takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of a successful prevention program, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Enterprise promptly addresses recommendations to improve safety that result from facility Process Hazard Analysis, Accident Prevention Program Audits and Incident Investigations.  In addition, location technicians are encouraged to recommend

ed safeguards or procedural changes that will improve the safety of the operations at Alma Terminal.  The following is a list of improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

* The safety management/accident prevention program is currently being reviewed and revised to ensure that safety management practices at Alma Terminal meet approved company standards.
* A new video monitoring and surveillance system has recently been installed at the Alma Terminal.
* A new infra-red and programmable logic controller based fire detection system has recently been installed at the terminal. 
* The Alma Terminal in currently reviewing the facility Emergency Response Plan for completeness and recommendation of possible improvements.
 .
